results.title: Expressing a twentieth century vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program probes how the photograph has been used as a metaphor to describe the photographer’s inner state. This is in contrast to traditional approaches to realistic photography. Individual photographers discuss the use of metaphor in their own experiences and works.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute

results.title: The Family album
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing image”.
Highlights the most frequent subject of photographers past and present, the family portrait. Provides a history of family portraiture, including daguerreotypes and wet-plate photography, as well as the development of Kodak roll-film cameras. Includes interviews with leading contemporary photographers who specialise in family portraiture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute

results.title: Solutions to images
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program contains a technical survey of the main photographic processes from the daguerreotype to the Kodak#1. Explores an antique tintype gallery and shows a wet-collodion negative made during the American Civil War.

results.title: The Developing image
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description: Explores the marvellous invention of the camera, using colour and music to evoke the period. This series takes viewers from the daguerreotype to wet plate to tintype and onwards examining hundreds of exemplary photographs. It dramatically depicts various themes in the history of photography.

results.title: A Conversation with Wilson Bryan Key
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Developing image”.
Dr. Key is a professor of Media Studies and president of Media Probe, a centre for the study of Media. Dr. Key attempts to awaken the public to the real message behind the innumerable photographic images which surround us. This fascinating discussion focuses on subliminal advertising, and how millions of dollars are spent each year for the solitary purpose of persuading consumers to buy a product.

results.title: Light from within
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Developing image”.
Examines the artistic aspects of photography, comparing it with trends in modern art, and deals with early and contemporary creative photography. The trend towards graphic experimentation is examined through a discussion with contemporary photographers who are leading practitioners in their fields.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute

results.title: Illusions of reality
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Developing image”.
Portrays the public’s belief in the photograph and the ways that this trust has been manipulated over the years. Viewers explore photographs taken at the Battle of Gettysburg with a Civil War historian, while contemporary photographer Duane Michals, discusses illusion in his personal and commercial work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute

results.title: Witness to the American experience
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Developing image”.
Examines the importance of photographs as an historical record of the American experience, and suggests that care must be taken in accepting the photographs as unbiased or entirely realistic. Viewers visit American Civil War locations as they look today and compare them to historical records. Through photographs, the emotions of a community deep in economical and psychological depression at the turn-of-the-century, are highlighted.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute

results.title: The Famine within
results.brief_description: The Famine within is a Canadian feature length documentary film about the contemporary obsession with body size and shape. Under the coercive powers of consumerism and the mass media, women have come to view their bodies as marketable objects and to judge them according to the unrealistic standards of the body ideal. Combining the direct testimony of many women who have suffered from body obsession, this film explores the kind of hunger that cannot be satisfied by food. Best Feature Documentary 1991 Genie Awards (Canada).
results.description: The Famine within is a Canadian feature length documentary film about the contemporary obsession with body size and shape. Combining the direct testimony of many women who have suffered from body obsession, this film explores the kind of hunger that cannot be satisfied by food. results.title: Beyond our vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Developing image”.
The need for accurate recording through photographs is examined, in both the past and the present. The program explores Western survey photography, including an original Western survey album used to persuade Congress to make Yellowstone National Park, Eadweard Muybridge’s stop-action photography and Landsat satellite imagery. Photography can now provide viewers insight into places, objects and events, beyond their personal experience.
